{{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-190-07-B |Item_parent=Prolonged fever |Item_parent_short=Prolonged fever |Rank=B |Title=Knowing the diagnostic approach and the strategy for prioritising complementary examinations |Description=None |Rubric=Complementary examinations |Contributors= |Order=7}} ==Biological tests o CBC, with blood smear analysis o C-reactive protein (acute or chronic inflammatory syndrome, elevated C-reactive protein (CRP))'''' o Serum protein electrophoresis o Blood ionogram, creatinine, calcium levels o Transaminases, gammaGT, alkaline phosphatases, bilirubin o Creatine kinase (CK), lactic dehydrogenase (LDH) o TSHus (thyroid-stimulating hormone ultra-sensitive) o Activated partial thromboplastin time, prothrombin time, fibrinogen o Ferritin o Anti-nuclear antibodies, rheumatoid factor, anti-neutrophil cytoplasm antibodies o Proteinuria (ratio of proteinuria to creatininuria, based on a urine sample)
==Microbiological tests o Blood cultures (x 3), before any antibiotic treatment o Urine cytobacteriological examination o Epstein Barr virus (EBV), cytomegalovirus (CMV), human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) serologies (and others depending on epidemiology). ==''In second line or according to clinical context'''== o Digestive endoscopy o Temporal artery biopsy if > 50 years old '''In children as first-line treatment at D7''' Biological and microbiological tests - CBC, CRP, fibrinogen, VS, HAA, iono ASAT ALAT ALAT, ferritin - Blood cultures - EBV, CMV, parvovirus serology - BU (with leucocytes and proteinuria) + ECBU '''- Morphological examinations:'''' Chest X-ray, abdominal ultrasound, cardiac ultrasound If the fever persists beyond this point without any obvious explanation, a paediatric specialist opinion is required (= for the 3rd cycle). to find out more about children: https://pap-pediatrie.fr/files/fievre_prolongee.pdf

question.title: What is the recommended approach for children with a prolonged fever?
question.description: A child with a prolonged fever requires a comprehensive diagnostic approach to determine the underlying cause.

option_a.title: Biological and microbiological tests only
option_a.description: This approach focuses on testing for infections and inflammation, but may not consider other potential causes.

option_b.title: Morphological examinations only
option_b.description: This approach relies on imaging studies like X-rays and ultrasounds, but may not identify underlying infections or inflammation.

option_c.title: A combination of biological and microbiological tests, plus morphological examinations
option_c.description: This comprehensive approach considers multiple factors, including infections, inflammation, and anatomical abnormalities.

option_d.title: A pediatric specialist opinion, regardless of previous test results
option_d.description: This approach prioritizes expert evaluation over empirical testing, but may not consider the child's overall clinical picture.

correct_option.title: A combination of biological and microbiological tests, plus morphological examinations
